item.title: GPO Abuse - Part 1
item.description: Group Policy Objects (GPOs) is a subject I’ve wanted to write about for a long time and I’m happy to have finally started.

item.title: AmsiScanBuffer Bypass - Part 4
item.description: As 2018 rapidly comes to an end, I thought I’d close out the year by clearing up some confusions over this AmsiScanBuffer bypass and why it appears to fail under some circumstances.

item.title: AmsiScanBuffer Bypass - Part 3
item.description: In Part 2, we engineered a delivery method for the AmsiScanBuffer Bypass discussed in Part 1. In this post, we’ll make some modifications to the bypass itself.

item.title: AmsiScanBuffer Bypass - Part 2
item.description:
In Part 1, we had a brief look at the AmsiScanBuffer bypass technique. We found some circumstances where the bypass code would be identified as malicious before it could be executed (which turned out to be a simple string detection), and modified the code to circumvent this.

In this post, we’ll explore a delivery method to help stage a Cobalt Strike / Empire / <insert framework here> agent. As with Part 1, this is not about some 1337 code drop - it’s a demonstration of how I walked through engineering the final result.

So, let’s get cracking.

item.title: AmsiScanBuffer Bypass - Part 1
item.description: Andre Marques recently posted a pretty nice write-up for circumventing AMSI, based on previous work by CyberArk.

item.title: A Lesson in .NET Framework Versions
item.description: With the emergence of more C# and .NET tooling, I occasionally see people tripping up over this. It’s not a huge issue, just something to be aware of.

item.title: Enumerating AppLocker Config
item.description: Very quick post to explore some different ways to enumerate the AppLocker configuration being applied to a host, both remotely and locally. Understanding these rules, particularly deny rules, are useful for engineering bypasses.

item.title: RDPClip
item.description: This is just a quick post to demonstrate some interesting aspects of the Remote Desktop Clipboard Monitor.

item.title: CSharp, DotNetToJScript, XSL
item.description: In April 2018, Casey Smith published a finding he dubbed squiblytwo, which detailed how WMIC can be used to invoke arbitary code contained in the extensible stylesheet language (XSL) format.

item.title: Review: Active Directory Attacks for Red and Blue Teams
item.description: Along with Cn33liz, I recently had the pleasure of assisting Nikhil Mittal with his 2018 BruCON spring training: Active Directory Attacks for Red and Blue Teams.

item.title: A View of Persistence
item.description: Persistence, noun, the continued or prolonged existence of something.

item.title: LAPS - Part 2
item.description: In Part 1 we explored how one could go about discovering and mapping the LAPS configuration in a domain. In this part, we’ll look at various ways LAPS can be abused for persistence purposes.

item.title: LAPS - Part 1
item.description: I suspect the majority of folk are familiar with the “Local Administrator Password Solution” (LAPS) from Microsoft. If not, the tl;dr is that it: periodically changes the local admin account password stores the password in a extended attribute of the computer object in AD allows password read & reset permissions to be delegated to AD users/groups More detailed information can be found here, here and here. The purpose of this post, is to put together a more complete end-to-end process for mapping out the LAPS configuration in a domain.

item.title: Red Team Infrastructure - AWS Encrypted EBS
item.description: Tim MalcomVetter caused a bit of stir over his Responsible Red Teams post last week, which is not surprising since he was pretty fucking rude about the whole thing.

item.title: VHD to DA
item.description: Where a 10-year old backup can fcuk you in the ass…

item.title: Automated Red Team Infrastructure Deployment with Terraform - Part 2
item.description:
Introduction

In Part 1, we looked at using Terraform to deploy cloud infrastructure (VMs, firewalls, DNS records etc). In this post, we’ll look at some examples for automating the installation of tools/software on the VM resources.

item.title: Jumping Network Segregation with RDP
item.description:
Introduction

This short post demonstrates how it may be possible to pivot into a segregated/protected network, via an RDP Jump Box.

item.title: Automated Red Team Infrastructure Deployment with Terraform - Part 1
item.description:
Introduction

Deploying resiliant Red Team infrastructure can be quite a time consuming process. This wiki maintained by Steve Borosh and Jeff Dimmock is probably the best public resource I’ve seen in regards to design considerations and hardening tips.

For someone like myself, who destroys and stands fresh infrastructure up for each engagement, building everything by hand is a long, laborious process. Anything that can be automated is a good thing.

item.title: How to Accidently Win Against AV
item.description: Computer viruses have been around since as early as the 1970’s - the eternal battle between virus creators and antivirus solutions continues to wage over 40 years later.

item.title: PsExec Much?
item.description: I recently completed an adversary simulation and thought I would write a short post about some of my experiences.

item.title: Playing with Cuckoo
item.description: After the release and complete hubbub that WannaCry caused, I thought it would be fun to play with Cuckoo Sandbox.

item.title: A Citrix Story
item.description: I recently had the pleasure of partaking in a Citrix Virtual Desktop infrastructure assessment.
